author: ELAN PERUMAL and STUART MICHAEL
title: Too fast and too furious
text:
by elan perumal and stuart michael A Mat Rempit doing the ‘superman’ along Persiaran Raja Muda Musa in Port Klang at about 4am in the morning on Saturday and Sunday. — Photos by Muhamad Shahril Rosli and videos by MOHSIN DADAMEAH and THANARAJ LETCHUMANAN/The Star 
Mat Rempit take over the main streets in Klang Valley in the wee hours of the weekend. Riding recklessly on their 'kapcai', they cause noise pollution and are a menace to other road users. StarMetro checks out a few popular spots these hell riders reign supreme. 
PERSIARAN Raja Muda Musa in Klang is a busy road during weekdays as many use it to get to the Federal Highway and other highways. 
However, after midnight on Fridays and Saturdays it becomes an illegal race track with hundreds of Mat Rempit gathering to race against each other. 
Most of them modified their motorcycles to go fast and give a louder “vroom” sound. 
Some of the bolder members of the group even do the wheelie, ride without holding the handle or lie on their stomach. 
The usual meeting spot are from the U-turn under a flyover at Taman Gembira, Klang and the traffic light junction leading to Jalan Sungai Keladi and Jalan Kastam just before Port Klang town. 
There is also a shorter route from the Pandamaran Sports Complex to the Jalan Sungai Keladi and Jalan Kastam traffic lights. 
Once the race starts, there is no adherence to traffic rules and traffic lights and whoever stands in their way runs the risk of getting abused or attacked by the Mat Rempit . 
The race usually starts and finishes at the same spot. 
Not only do they ride fast and recklessly, the Mat Rempit also get furious if other road users get in their way. 
They would often harass or bully them by surrounding the lone vehicle as if to say, “Get out of the way, this is our road!” 
Allan Lim, 36, who was returning late after attending an event on a Saturday last month, said a group of bikers weaved across his vehicle at the Federal Highway as though telling him to get out of the way. 
“It is scary when these bikers come so close to your car and criss-cross dangerously. An accident can easily happen. 
“They have no regard for their safety and for other motorists,” he said. 
A motorists, identified only as Wong, said when he drove towards Taman Tun Dr Ismail, Kuala Lumpur about 3am, a group of Mat Rempit prevented other vehicles from passing by, blocking all the four lanes. 
Wong tried to overtake them but was blocked by about 40 bikers. 
“I was shocked that one of the bikers sprayed my front windscreen with a fire extinguisher. 
“I had no choice but to stop my vehicle in the middle of the road as I could not see the road. 
“After the bikers left, I washed off the foam with water,” he said, swearing to avoid the Mat Rempit after that incident. 
These Mat Rempit also cause sleepless nights for those living in shoplots and flats along Persiaran Raja Muda Musa when they race which is normally a noisy affair. 
A flat dweller along the Federal Highway in Shah Alam, known only as James, said he and his family had to endure sleepless nights during the weekends because of the Mat Rempit menace. 
“The loud sound from the motorbikes when they race during the wee hours of the morning disrupts our peace,” added James. 
The Mat Rempit also have spectators who come with their own kapcai , some with female pillion riders, gathering at Jalan Kim Chuan and Kampung Raja Uda in Port Klang. 
These spectators, who gather in big numbers, have no qualms blocking the roads, to get a good view of the illegal race. 
Based on StarMetro’s observation, these Mat Rempit would initially offer the spectators a “trailer” or “warm-up” races just after midnight to allow bets to be placed. 
The real deal or actual races takes place between 3am and 6am. 
These races are repeated and the winner is decided on the number of times a rider comes out tops. 
Besides Klang, Bandar Setia Alam and the stretch between Batu Tiga and Padang Jawa along the Federal Highway where the notorious Mat Rempit race. 
At Setia Alam, the race starts along Persiaran Setia Alam which connects Jalan Meru to the toll booth leading to the New Klang Valley Expressway. 
On Saturday, about 30 Mat Rempit gathered at the Jalan Glenmarie traffic light junction leading to the Batu Tiga flyover on the Federal Highway just after midnight on Saturday. 
It started under the flyover, heading for the Padang Jawa interchange where the racers made a U-turn and headed back to where they started. 
The illegal races went on until 4am. 
Some of them would head to nearby petrol stations for a break before resuming the race. 
To avoid detection by the authorities, the racers often used heavily tinted visors on their helmets. 
The Mat Rempit mostly in their 20s and early 30s, enjoy performing stunts and dangerous manoeuvres to the delight of onlookers. 
Motorists want the police to take action against the Mat Rempit saying that they have gone overboard. 
Attempts to obtain comments from the police on actions taken to reduce the Mat Rempit menace was unsuccessful.
